result.execSummary:
The defendant Barry J Krznarich was found guilty of the following charge(s) in this case.

  • Possess w/ Intent-LSD (>1-5grams), a class F felony, Wisconsin Statutes 961.41(1m)(f)2.

Notice to employers: It may be a violation of state law to discriminate against a job applicant because of an arrest or conviction record. Generally speaking, an employer may refuse to hire an applicant on the basis of a conviction only if the circumstances of the conviction substantially relate to the particular job. For more information, see Wisconsin Statute 111.335 and the Department of Workforce Development's publication, Arrest and Conviction Records under the Law.

supervisions.notes:
Pay $500.00 fine plus costs.   Payment is due within 30 days.  If the Defendant cannot make the payment, he/she must report to the Clerk of Courts Office to set up a payment plan.  Failure to comply will result in other collection methods including a civil Judgment and/or suspension of your drivers license for one (1) years.  This judgment may be collected by income assignment if you fail to pay fines and costs as ordered.
--------------------------------

Provide biological specimen to state crime lab for DNA analysis, and pay DNA analysis surcharge.
--------------------------------

records.addlTxt: BOND QUASHED

Defendant Barry J Krznarich in court by telephone with attorney Jeremy J Guza.  Andrew Herrmann appeared for the State of Wisconsin.  Minutes filed.  Final pre-trial scheduled for February 1, 2017 at 02:30 pm.  Jury trial - 12 person scheduled for February 6, 2017 at 08:30 am.

Defendant Barry J Krznarich in court with attorney Jeremy J Guza.  Andrew Robert Herrmann appeared for the State of Wisconsin.  Minutes filed.  Status conference scheduled for September 30, 2016 at 01:15 pm.

Scheduling Order
Copies provided to Counsel in Court on this date
Attorneys provided with copy of Pre-trial Order at time of hearing on May 20, 2016

2:30 pm  Court in session.  Case called.  Appearances given.  
Deft Barry J Krznarich appears by phone with Atty Jeremy J Guza who is present in Courtroom.  
Haley Jo Johnson appeared for the State of Wisconsin.  
Court makes record that the Deputy was able to conduct a Terry Stop based upon his observations which the Court found to be credible.  Argument by Atty Guza that the Officer did not actually see something being exchanged.  Defense believes there is no merit for obstructing.  Court reads from transcript of motion hearing.  Court believes it is clear from Deputy Martin's perspective that he saw something being exchanged between the two individuals.  Atty Guza references some of the cross examination questions from the Motion hearing transcript which he reads into the record.   Response by Atty Johnson.  Court makes findings and denies the Defense motion for the reason set forth on the record.  
Atty Guza enters a NOT GUILTY plea on the defendant's behalf
Court schedules status conference and will allow Mr. Kznarich to appear by phone for the status conference.  
Attorney's are provided with a copy of the Court's Scheduling order.  
Motion deadline will be the same date as the Status Conference  Status conference scheduled for July 21, 2016 at 01:15 pm.
Defendant's Memorandum on the Issues

Oral Ruling before the Hon. David M. Reddy on April 14, 2016
Court reporter - Eileen Grzenia

4:00 pm  Court in session.  Case called.  Appearances given.  
Andrew Robert Herrmann appeared for the State of Wisconsin.  
Defendant Barry J Krznarich in court with attorney Jeremy J Guza.  .
Matter is before the Court for an Oral ruling on the defense Motion to Suppress.  
The Court is ready to make an initial ruling but then has some questions for the Attorneys.  
Court makes a record as to specific facts which leads the Court to believe that Deputy Martin had reasonable suspicion to believe that a crime had been committed.  
Court believes Deputy Martin's testimony was credible.  Court reads portions of the transcript from the Motion hearing into the record.  
Response by Atty Herrmann to Court's question as to whether Deputy Martin requested the defendant to empty his pockets or was told to empty them?  
Atty Herrmann reads further portions from the transcript into the record.  
Response by Atty Guza arguing that Deputy Martin was telling the defendant to empty his pockets and there was no option for the defendant.  
Court believes the request was dealing with the other pockets.  Court asks what was the significance of the defendant being ordered to empty pockets when Deputy Martin is conducting a Terry Stop?  
Response by Atty Guza.  
Court asks since he didn't have his hands in his pockets, does that mean the Deputy couldn't order him to empty his pockets?  
Argument by Atty Guza.  Continued discussion between Court and Attys.  
Atty Herrmann wasn't prepared to answer any further questions today as he believed this was just going to be an oral ruling by the Court.  Court can appreciate that and may give the Attys an opportunity to further brief this matter.   Court would like Attorneys to address Sumner and Kyles factors and brief whether the pat down or frisk was also constitutionally permitted.  Atty Guza argues there was no justification for a Terry frisk.  There was no Officer safety at issue in this case.  Court needs an answer to these questions before the Court can make a ruling.  Court is asking for further briefing on these issues.  Court asks that Atty Johnson be present at the next hearing in case there are further questions.  Atty Guza can file his brief by April 29th.  State has until May 13th to respond.  

TWO ISSUES TO TO ADDRESS:  
1)  Whether Deputy Martin's order that Mr. Krznarich empty his pockets is consititutionally permitted.
2)  Constitutionality of the frisk - In particular, the Court is concerned that the State didn't address all of the factors in Kyles and Sumner
Court is finding that it was an order to empty his pockets and not a request. 
Matter set for further hearing.  
4:26 pm  Court in recess.  Motion hearing scheduled for May 20, 2016 at 02:30 pm.
**Transcript filed on 04-20-16**  (ls)
Response to Krznarich's brief in support of his motion to suppress
Defendant's Brief in support of motion to suppress
State's Brief in response to Defendant's Motion to Suppress Fruits of Illegal Seizure

Transcript of Motion hearing before the Hon. David M. Reddy on 02/15/2016
Court Reporter:  Sandra Elderbrook
In Court file

9:31 am  Court in sesison.  Case called.  Appearances given.   
Atty Haley Jo Johnson appeared for the State of Wisconsin.  
Defendant Barry J Krznarich in court with Atty Jeremy J Guza.  
Matter is before the Court on the Defendant's Motion to Suppress.  
Attys have spoken and are requesting that they be allowed to file briefs on this issue after testimony is taken today.  
9:33 am  Court is fine with proceeding with the proposal of parties and will hear testimony only today.  
9:33 am  Deputy Ira Martin is sworn and testifies on exam of Attorney Johnson.  
9:50 am  Exhibit 1 marked and identified.
9:54 am  Response by Deputy Martin to Court's questions.  
9:54 am  Cross exam of Deputy Martin by Attorney Guza.  
10:05 am  Redirect by Atty Johnson.
10:06 am  Recross by Attorney Guza.  
10:07 am  Court makes record as to demonstration of what Deputy Martin believed he saw that day.  
10:08 am  Continued recross by Atty Guza.  
10:09 am  Attorneys have no further testimony to present.
State's Brief due March 14th
Deft's Response Brief due March 28th
Reply by State due April 4th
Court schedules hearing for decision.  
Defendant is from California and Court will allow him to appear by phone for the next hearing.  
Defendant is instructed to call the main number for the Clerk's office.  
10:15 am  Court in recess.  Oral ruling scheduled for April 14, 2016 at 04:00 pm.

to person posting bond money

MUST POST $500.00 CASH 

Defendant shall not possess or consume alcohol.  Defendant shall not drive a motor vehicle without a valid driver's license.  Defendant shall not possess or use illegal drugs or drug paraphernalia.  Defendant will not possess any guns or other weapons.  Defendant will not in any way contact or attempt to contact any victim(s) listed and will avoid their residence/place of employment or any place they are located and will avoid causing any other person, other than defendant's attorney, from doing so on defendant's behalf.  The term "no contact" is hereby defined as through the mail, by telephone, by way of electronic device, in person, or through a third party.  VICTIM(S)/RESIDENCE(S): NO CONTACT WITH ALPINE VALLEY RESORT OR MUSIC THEATRE.
